verses.text: By and by, when it came to a question of capture, he departed from him during the examination before Pilate.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 27:14
verses.text: In like manner, his mother's seed did not admit of being injured, being equally exempt from all manner of outrage, and being undiscovered even by the Demiurge himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 27:15
verses.text: The animal and carnal Christ, however, does suffer after the fashion of the superior Christ, who, for the purpose of producing Achamoth, had been stretched upon the cross, that is, Horos, in a substantial though not a cognizable form.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 27:16
verses.text: In this manner do they reduce all things to mere images—Christians themselves being indeed nothing but imaginary beings!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 28:1
verses.text: The Demiurge Cured of His Ignorance by the Saviour's Advent, from Whom He Hears of the Great Future in Store for Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 28:2
verses.text: Meanwhile the Demiurge, being still ignorant of everything, although he will actually have to make some announcement himself by the prophets, but is quite incapable of even this part of his duty (because they divide authority over the prophets between Achamoth, the Seed, and the Demiurge), no sooner heard of the advent of Soter (Saviour) than he runs to him with haste and joy, with all his might, like the centurion in the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 28:3
verses.text: And being enlightened by him on all points, he learns from him also of his own prospect how that he is to succeed to his mother's place.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 28:4
verses.text: Being thenceforth free from all care, he carries on the administration of this world, mainly under the plea of protecting the church, for as long a time as may be necessary and proper.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:1
verses.text: The Three Natures Again Adverted to.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:2
verses.text: They are All Exemplified Amongst Men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:3
verses.text: For Instance, by Cain, and Abel, and Seth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:4
verses.text: I will now collect from different sources, by way of conclusion, what they affirm concerning the dispensation of the whole human race.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:5
verses.text: Having at first stated their views as to man's threefold nature—which was, however, united in one in the case of Adam—they then proceed after him to divide it (into three) with their especial characteristics, finding opportunity for such distinction in the posterity of Adam himself, in which occurs a threefold division as to moral differences.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:6
verses.text: Cain and Abel, and Seth, who were in a certain sense the sources of the human race, become the fountain-heads of just as many qualities of nature and essential character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:7
verses.text: The material nature, which had become reprobate for salvation, they assign to Cain; the animal nature, which was poised between divergent hopes, they find in Abel; the spiritual, preordained for certain salvation, they store up in Seth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:8
verses.text: In this way also they make a twofold distinction among souls, as to their property of good and evil—according to the material condition derived from Cain, or the animal from Abel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:9
verses.text: Men's spiritual state they derive over and above the other conditions, from Seth adventitiously, not in the way of nature, but of grace, in such wise that Achamoth infuses it among superior beings like rain into good souls, that is, those who are enrolled in the animal class.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:10
verses.text: Whereas the material class—in other words, those which are bad souls—they say, never receive the blessings of salvation; for that nature they have pronounced to be incapable of any change or reform in its natural condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:11
verses.text: This grain, then, of spiritual seed is modest and very small when cast from her hand, but under her instruction increases and advances into full conviction, as we have already said; and the souls, on this very account, so much excelled all others, that the Demiurge, even then in his ignorance, held them in great esteem.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 29:12
verses.text: For it was from their list that he had been accustomed to select men for kings and for priests; and these even now, if they have once attained to a full and complete knowledge of these foolish conceits of theirs, since they are already naturalized in the fraternal bond of the spiritual state, will obtain a sure salvation, nay, one which is on all accounts their due.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:1
verses.text: The Lax and Dangerous Views of This Sect Respecting Good Works.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:2
verses.text: That These are Unnecessary to the Spiritual Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:3
verses.text: For this reason it is that they neither regard works as necessary for themselves, nor do they observe any of the calls of duty, eluding even the necessity of martyrdom on any pretence which may suit their pleasure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:4
verses.text: For this rule, (they say), is enjoined upon the animal seed, in order that the salvation, which we do not possess by any privilege of our state, we may work out by right of our conduct.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:5
verses.text: Upon us, who are of an imperfect nature, is imprinted the mark of this (animal) seed, because we are reckoned as sprung from the loves of Theletus, and consequently as an abortion, just as their mother was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:6
verses.text: But woe to us indeed, should we in any point transgress the yoke of discipline, should we grow dull in the works of holiness and justice, should we desire to make our confession anywhere else, I know not where, and not before the powers of this world at the tribunals of the chief magistrates! As for them, however, they may prove their nobility by the dissoluteness of their life and their diligence in sin, since Achamoth fawns on them as her own; for she, too, found sin no unprofitable pursuit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:7
verses.text: Now it is held amongst them, that, for the purpose of honouring the celestial marriages, it is necessary to contemplate and celebrate the mystery always by cleaving to a companion, that, is to a woman; otherwise (they account any man) degenerate, and a bastard to the truth, who spends his life in the world without loving a woman or uniting himself to her.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 30:8
verses.text: Then what is to become of the eunuchs whom we see amongst them?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:1
verses.text: At the Last Day Great Changes Take Place Amongst the aeons as Well as Among Men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:2
verses.text: How Achamoth and the Demiurge are Affected Then.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:3
verses.text: Irony on the Subject.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:4
verses.text: It remains that we say something about the end of the world, and the dispensing of reward.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:5
verses.text: As soon as Achamoth has completed the full harvest of her seed, and has then proceeded to gather it into her garner, or, after it has been taken to the mill and ground to flour, has hidden it in the kneading-trough with yeast until the whole be leavened, then shall the end speedily come.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:6
verses.text: Then, to begin with, Achamoth herself removes from the middle region, from the second stage to the highest, since she is restored to the Pleroma: she is immediately received by that paragon of perfection Soter, as her spouse of course, and they two afterwards consummate new nuptials.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:7
verses.text: This must be the spouse of the Scripture, the Pleroma of espousals (for you might suppose that the Julian laws were interposing, since there are these migrations from place to place).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:8
verses.text: In like manner, the Demiurge, too, will then change the scene of his abode from the celestial Hebdomad to the higher regions, to his mother's now vacant saloon—by this time knowing her, without however seeing her.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 31:9
verses.text: (A happy coincidence!) For if he had caught a glance of her, he would have preferred never to have known her.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:1
verses.text: Indignant Irony Exposing the Valentinian Fable About the Judicial Treatment of Mankind at the Last Judgment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:2
verses.text: The Immorality of the Doctrine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:3
verses.text: As for the human race, its end will be to the following effect:—To all which bear the earthy and material mark there accrues an entire destruction, because "all flesh is grass," and amongst these is the soul of mortal man, except when it has found salvation by faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:4
verses.text: The souls of just men, that is to say, our souls, will be conveyed to the Demiurge in the abodes of the middle region.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:5
verses.text: We are duly thankful; we shall be content to be classed with our god, in whom lies our own origin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:6
verses.text: Into the palace of the Pleroma nothing of the animal nature is admitted—nothing but the spiritual swarm of Valentinus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:7
verses.text: There, then, the first process is the despoiling of men themselves, that is, men within the Pleroma.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:8
verses.text: Now this despoiling consists of the putting off of the souls in which they appear to be clothed, which they will give back to their Demiurge as they had obtained them from him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:9
verses.text: They will then become wholly intellectual spirits—impalpable, invisible—and in this state will be readmitted invisibly to the Pleroma—stealthily, if the case admits of the idea.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:10
verses.text: What then?  They will be dispersed amongst the angels, the attendants on Soter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:11
verses.text: As sons, do you suppose? Not at all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:12
verses.text: As servants, then? No, not even so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:13
verses.text: Well, as phantoms? Would that it were nothing more! Then in what capacity, if you are ashamed to tell us? In the capacity of brides.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:14
verses.text: Then will they end their Sabine rapes with the sanction of wedlock.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:15
verses.text: This will be the guerdon of the spiritual, this the recompense of their faith! Such fables have their use.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:16
verses.text: Although but a Marcus or a Gaius, full-grown in this flesh of ours, with a beard and such like proofs (of virility,) it may be a stern husband, a father, a grandfather, a great-grandfather (never mind what, in fact, if only a male), you may perhaps in the bridal-chamber of the Pleroma—I have already said so tacitly—even become the parent by an angel of some aeon of high numerical rank.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:17
verses.text: For the right celebration of these nuptials, instead of the torch and veil, I suppose that secret fire is then to burst forth, which, after devastating the whole existence of things, will itself also be reduced to nothing at last, after everything has been reduced to ashes; and so their fable too will be ended.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:18
verses.text: But I, too, am no doubt a rash man, in having exposed so great a mystery in so derisive a way: I ought to be afraid that Achamoth, who did not choose to make herself known even to her own son, would turn mad, that Theletus would be enraged, that Fortune would be irritated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:19
verses.text: But I am yet a liege-man of the Demiurge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:20
verses.text: I have to return after death to the place where there is no more giving in marriage, where I have to be clothed upon rather than to be despoiled,—where, even if I am despoiled of my sex, I am classed with angels—not a male angel, nor a female one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 32:21
verses.text: There will be no one to do aught against me, nor will they then find any male energy in me.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:1
verses.text: These Remaining Chapters an Appendix to the Main Work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:2
verses.text: In This Chapter Tertullian Notices a Difference Among Sundry Followers of Ptolemy, a Disciple of Valentinus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:3
verses.text: I shall now at last produce, by way of finale, after so long a story, those points which, not to interrupt the course of it, and by the interruption distract the reader's attention, I have preferred reserving to this place.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:4
verses.text: They have been variously advanced by those who have improved on the doctrines of Ptolemy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:5
verses.text: For there have been in his school "disciples above their master," who have attributed to their Bythus two wives—Cogitatio (Thought) and Voluntas (Will).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:6
verses.text: For Cogitatio alone was not sufficient wherewith to produce any offspring, although from the two wives procreation was most easy to him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:7
verses.text: The former bore him Monogenes (Only-Begotten) and Veritas (Truth).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:8
verses.text: Veritas was a female after the likeness of Cogitatio; Monogenes a male bearing a resemblance to Voluntas.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 33:9
verses.text: For it is the strength of Voluntas which procures the masculine nature, inasmuch as she affords efficiency to Cogitatio.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 34:1
verses.text: Other Varying Opinions Among the Valentinians Respecting the Deity, Characteristic Raillery.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 34:2
verses.text: Others of purer mind, mindful of the honour of the Deity, have, for the purpose of freeing him from the discredit of even single wedlock, preferred assigning no sex whatever to Bythus; and therefore very likely they talk of "this deity" in the neuter gender rather than "this god".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 34:3
verses.text: Others again, on the other hand, speak of him as both masculine and feminine, so that the worthy chronicler Fenestella must not suppose that an hermaphrodite was only to be found among the good people of Luna.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:1
verses.text: Yet More Discrepancies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:2
verses.text: Just Now the Sex of Bythus Was an Object of Dispute; Now His Rank Comes in Question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:3
verses.text: Absurd Substitutes for Bythus Criticised by Tertullian.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:4
verses.text: There are some who do not claim the first place for Bythus, but only a lower one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:5
verses.text: They put their Ogdoad in the foremost rank; itself, however, derived from a Tetrad, but under different names.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:6
verses.text: For they put Pro-arche (Before the Beginning) first, Anennoetos (Inconceivable) second, Arrhetos (Indescribable) third, Aoratos (Invisible) fourth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:7
verses.text: Then after Pro-arche they say Arche (Beginning) came forth and occupied the first and the fifth place; from Anennoetos came Acataleptos (Incomprehensible) in the second and the sixth place; from Arrhetos came Anonomastos (Nameless) in the third and the seventh place; from Aoratos came Agennetos (Unbegotten) in the fourth and the eight place.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:8
verses.text: Now by what method he arranges this, that each of these aeons should be born in two places, and that, too, at such intervals, I prefer to be ignorant of than to be informed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 35:9
verses.text: For what can be right in a system which is propounded with such absurd particulars?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:1
verses.text: Less Reprehensible Theories in the Heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:2
verses.text: Bad is the Best of Valentinianism.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:3
verses.text: How much more sensible are they who, rejecting all this tiresome nonsense, have refused to believe that any one aeon has descended from another by steps like these, which are really neither more nor less Gemonian; but that on a given signal the eight-fold emanation, of which we have heard, issued all at once from the Father and His Ennoea (Thought),—that it is, in fact, from His mere motion that they gain their designations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:4
verses.text: When, as they say, He thought of producing offspring, He on that account gained the name of Father.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:5
verses.text: After producing, because the issue which He produced was true, He received the name of Truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:6
verses.text: When He wanted Himself to be manifested, He on that account was announced as Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:7
verses.text: Those, moreover, whom He preconceived in His thought when He produced them, were then designated the Church.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:8
verses.text: As man, He uttered His Word; and so this Word is His first-begotten Son, and to the Word was added Life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:9
verses.text: And by this process the first Ogdoad was completed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 36:10
verses.text: However, the whole of this tiresome story is utterly poor and weak.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:1
verses.text: Other Turgid and Ridiculous Theories About the Origin of the aeons and Creation, Stated and Condemned.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:2
verses.text: Now listen to some other buffooneries of a master who is a great swell among them, and who has pronounced his dicta with an even priestly authority.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:3
verses.text: They run thus: There comes, says he, before all things Pro-arche, the inconceivable, and indescribable, and nameless, which I for my own part call Monotes (Solitude).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:4
verses.text: With this was associated another power, to which also I give the name of Henotes (Unity).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:5
verses.text: Now, inasmuch as Monotes and Henotes—that is to say, Solitude and Union—were only one being, they produced, and yet not in the way of production, the intellectual, innascible, invisible beginning of all things, which human language has called Monad (Solitude).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:6
verses.text: This has inherent in itself a consubstantial force, which it calls Unity These powers, accordingly, Solitude or Solitariness, and Unity, or Union, propagated all the other emanations of aeons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:7
verses.text: Wonderful distinction, to be sure! Whatever change Union and Unity may undergo, Solitariness and Solitude is profoundly supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 37:8
verses.text: Whatever designation you give the power, it is one and the same.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 38:1
verses.text: Diversity in the Opinions of Secundus, as Compared with the General Doctrine of Valentinus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 38:2
verses.text: Secundus is a trifle more human, as he is briefer: he divides the Ogdoad into a pair of Tetrads, a right hand one and a left hand one, one light and the other darkness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 38:3
verses.text: Only he is unwilling to derive the power which apostatized and fell away from any one of the aeons, but from the fruits which issued from their substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:1
verses.text: Their Diversity of Sentiment Affects the Very Central Doctrine of Christianity, Even the Person and Character of the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:2
verses.text: This Diversity Vitiates Every Gnostic School.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:3
verses.text: Now, concerning even the Lord Jesus, into how great a diversity of opinion are they divided! One party form Him of the blossoms of all the aeons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:4
verses.text: Another party will have it that He is made up only of those ten whom the Word and the Life produced; from which circumstance the titles of the Word and the Life were suitably transferred to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:5
verses.text: Others, again, that He rather sprang from the twelve, the offspring of Man and the Church, and therefore, they say, He was designated "Son of man".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:6
verses.text: Others, moreover, maintain that He was formed by Christ and the Holy Spirit, who have to provide for the establishment of the universe, and that He inherits by right His Father's appellation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:7
verses.text: Some there are who have imagined that another origin must be found for the title "Son of man;" for they have had the presumption to call the Father Himself Man, by reason of the profound mystery of this title: so that what can you hope for more ample concerning faith in that God, with whom you are now yourself on a par? Such conceits are constantly cropping out amongst them, from the redundance of their mother's seed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against the Valentinians 39:8
verses.text: And so it happens that the doctrines which have grown up amongst the Valentinians have already extended their rank growth to the woods of the Gnostics.
